turns.content: Aluminium grinding dust. ATEX Zone 22. GDB housing in FZ.

For the aluminium grinding dust application in the flour mill, you've specified a GDB housing in FZ material.The application exposes the system to Particulate Exposure, requiring mechanical filtration. Carbon filters are ineffective against solid particulates.Additionally, the presence of an Explosive Atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22) means that all components must be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Standard GDB housings with FZ material require grounding to comply with ATEX standards. The housing corrosion class is C2.To finalize the configuration, I need two details:

content_segments.text: For the flour mill application, you've specified a GDB-300x300 filter housing with FZ material and PG connection.
This application exposes the system to Particulate Exposure, which requires mechanical filtration to capture solid particulates. The GDB filter housing is suitable for this purpose.
Additionally, the presence of an Explosive Atmosphere means all components must be grounded to prevent ignition sources from static discharge. The housing corrosion class is C2.

The selected module (850 mÂ³/h capacity) is significantly oversized for the requested 150 mÂ³/h (18% utilization). This can lead to uneven air distribution and reduced efficiency. A more appropriate option would be a 300x600 mm module (1700 mÂ³/h capacity).

turns.content: Here is the specification for the GDB filter housing for your flour mill application.This configuration is suitable for indoor use and has a housing corrosion class of C2.The system will be exposed to Particulate Exposure from the flour milling process, requiring mechanical filtration to capture solid particulates. Also, given the presence of an Explosive Atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22), all components must be grounded to prevent ignition sources from static discharge. This requires grounding of all metallic housing components and the use of anti-static filter media.Please ensure that all installation guidelines for ATEX Zone 22 are followed.Note that the module capacity of 850 mÂ³/h is significantly higher than your required airflow of 150 mÂ³/h. This oversizing can lead to low face velocity and uneven air distribution. Consider using a smaller module size such as 300x600 mm or 600x300 mm for better performance.The selected module (850 mÂ³/h capacity) is significantly oversized for the requested 150 mÂ³/h (18% utilization). This can lead to uneven air distribution and reduced efficiency. A more appropriate option would be a 300x600 mm module (1700 mÂ³/h capacity).**Note**: Explosive atmosphere (ATEX zone) requires all components to be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Consider products with this trait**Note**: Explosive atmospheres require all components to prevent ignition sources. Static charge on ungrounded filter housings can produce sparks exceeding the minimum ignition energy of many dust/gas mixtures. MANDATORY REQUIREMENTS: (1) Grounding/earthing of all metallic housing components to prevent static discharge; (2) Anti-static filter media with conductive fibers or grounding strips â€” standard filter media is NOT suitable for ATEX zones; (3) Equipotential bonding between all housing sections; (4) Compliance with EN 60079-0 (general requirements) and EN 60079-31 (dust ignition protection). For Zone 22 (combustible dust): equipment must meet minimum Category 3D protection level. Non-negotiable â€” follow engineering recommendation

content_segments.text: Here is the specification for the GDB filter housing for your flour mill application.
This configuration is suitable for indoor use and has a housing corrosion class of C2.

The system will be exposed to Particulate Exposure from the flour milling process, requiring mechanical filtration to capture solid particulates. Also, given the presence of an Explosive Atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22), all components must be grounded to prevent ignition sources from static discharge. This requires grounding of all metallic housing components and the use of anti-static filter media.
content_segments.inference_logic: The application in a flour mill exposes the system to Particulate Exposure, requiring mechanical filtration. The Explosive Atmosphere requires grounding to prevent ignition.

content_segments.text: Please ensure that all installation guidelines for ATEX Zone 22 are followed.

Note that the module capacity of 850 mÂ³/h is significantly higher than your required airflow of 150 mÂ³/h. This oversizing can lead to low face velocity and uneven air distribution. Consider using a smaller module size such as 300x600 mm or 600x300 mm for better performance.

The selected module (850 mÂ³/h capacity) is significantly oversized for the requested 150 mÂ³/h (18% utilization). This can lead to uneven air distribution and reduced efficiency. A more appropriate option would be a 300x600 mm module (1700 mÂ³/h capacity).
**Note**: Explosive atmosphere (ATEX zone) requires all components to be electrostatically grounded to prevent spark ignition. Consider products with this trait

**Note**: Explosive atmospheres require all components to prevent ignition sources. Static charge on ungrounded filter housings can produce sparks exceeding the minimum ignition energy of many dust/gas mixtures. MANDATORY REQUIREMENTS: (1) Grounding/earthing of all metallic housing components to prevent static discharge; (2) Anti-static filter media with conductive fibers or grounding strips â€” standard filter media is NOT suitable for ATEX zones; (3) Equipotential bonding between all housing sections; (4) Compliance with EN 60079-0 (general requirements) and EN 60079-31 (dust ignition protection). For Zone 22 (combustible dust): equipment must meet minimum Category 3D protection level. Non-negotiable â€” follow engineering recommendation
